Title: Phylogenetic conservatism in plant phenology
TakeHome: Flowering and leafout times show phylogenetic signal because responses to cues are phylogenetically conserved
RelevancetoOurPaper: High - sets basis for our study
AddNotes: They measure phylogenetic signal in timings, not responses

Title: Meta-analysis of phenotypic selection on flowering phenology suggests that early flowering plants are favoured
TakeHome: Phylogenetic meta-analyses does not improve ordinary meta-analysis, but using phylogeny modifies the significance of predictors for flowering time
RelevancetoOurPaper: Mid-high - phylogenies may not matter in meta-analytic approaches
AddNotes: The authors do not directly test phylogenetic signal of phenology

Title: Conservatism and diversification of plant functional traits: Evolutionary rates versus phylogenetic signal
TakeHome: Evolutionary rate and phylogenetic signal may be unrelated
RelevancetoOurPaper: Low - perhaps to interpret final results
AddNotes: Should we plot traitgrams? So far we have not been thinking about diversificatioon at all.

Title: Time - size tradeoffs: a phylogenetic comparative study of flowering time, plant height and seed mass in a north-temperate flora
TakeHome: Correlations between flowering phenology and functional traits (seed size, height) differ between perennial herbs and woody plants
RelevancetoOurPaper: Low - but old study accounting for phylogeny-phenology

Title: Contraints and competition in the evolution of flowering phenology
TakeHome: Phylogenetic membership and life form strongly influence a species' flowering time
RelevancetoOurPaper: High - sets basis for our study
AddNotes: competition for pollination does not seem to push species' flowering times beyond seasonal boundaries

Title: Phylogenetic patterns of species loss in Thoreau's woods are driven by climate change
TakeHome: flowering-time response traits are shared among closely related species.
RelevancetoOurPaper: High - supports importance of phylogeny to phenology
AddNotes: They conclude that the effects of climate change on biodiversity would be phylogenetically biased

Title: Spring predictability explains different leaf?out strategies in the woody floras of North America, Europe and East Asia
TakeHome: species from regions with high STV have higher winter chilling requirements, and, leaf out later than related species from regions with lower STV
RelevancetoOurPaper: Low-mid - we do not have data to test procedence, but something to perhaps discuss

Title: On the importance of accounting for intraspecific genomic relatedness in multi-species studies
TakeHome: Methods paper showing how to include inter and intraspecific variation in ecological models with an example using the Flynn & Wolkovich data
RelevancetoOurPaper: Low-mid: Limited species (10) but did find 0.7 for signal and does suggest intraspecific variation matters, so worth mentioning I think.

Title: The phylogenetic mixed model
Predicting phenology by integrating ecology, evolution and climate science
TakeHome: Overview in regards to phylogeny: Lays out how phylogeny might matter in terms of predicting missing species, projecting forward for adaptive potential. Also, nicely outlines this " Phylogenetic approaches can map both raw observational phenology data, such as flowering dates, as well as model estimates of how strongly species cue to different environmental vari- ables such as temperature (Bolmgren & Cowan, 2008; Willis et al., 2008; Davis et al., 2010)." Not sure if the rates are possible and I think the community assembly stuff is out of fashion.
RelevancetoOurPaper: Mid-high: See section starting on 3636 for a nice overview

Title: Phylogenetic analysis and comparative data: a test and review of evidence
A global test for phylogenetic signal in shifts in flowering time under climate change
TakeHome: Signal in flowing shift (which is just a binned version of slope), but not slope so not sure on signal overall (trust molecular tree results; I recommend ignoring phylomatic results); OU models fit better
RelevancetoOurPaper: Mid-cited a lot so worth mentioning, but does lots of dodgey things so be sure to read carefully.

Title: Phenological responses to climate change do not exhibit phylogenetic signal in a subalpine plant community

Species' traits predict phenological responses to climate change in butterflies

Pollination mode predicts phenological response to climate change in terrestrial orchids: a case study from central E urope
The shared influence of phylogeny and ecology on the reproductive patterns of Myrteae (Myrtaceae)
Flowering phenology, growth forms, and pollination syndromes in tropical dry forest species: Influence of phylogeny and abiotic factors
Phylogenetic conservatism and trait correlates of spring phenological responses to climate change in northeast China
Phylogenetic conservatism and climate factors shape flowering phenology in alpine meadows
Reproductive phenology of Melastomataceae species with contrasting reproductive systems: contemporary and historical drivers
Herbarium specimens show patterns of fruiting phenology in native and invasive plant species across New England
Phenology of a dipterocarp forest with seasonal drought: Insights into the origin of general flowering
Fast and Cheap in the Fall: Phylogenetic determinants of late flowering phenologies in Himalayan Rhododendron
Contrasting growth phenology of native and invasive forest shrubs mediated by genome size
Phenological tracking enables positive species responses to climate change
Phylogeny, fruit traits, and ecological correlates of fruiting phenology in a Neotropical dry forest
Macroevolutionary constraints to tolerance: trade?offs with drought tolerance and phenology, but not resistance
Temperature controls phenology in continuously flowering Protea species of subtropical Africa
Asynchrony of seasons: genetic differentiation associated with geographic variation in climatic seasonality and reproductive phenology
Innately shorter vegetation periods in North American species explain native–non-native phenological asymmetries
Day length unlikely to constrain climate-driven shifts in leaf-out times of northern woody plants
Leaf out times of temperate woody plants are related to phylogeny, deciduousness, growth habit and wood anatomy
Detrending phenological time series improves climate–phenology analyses and reveals evidence of plasticity
